Thoughts :: Music industry addiction

June 14th, 2020
A hippo in a flower field.

Why may you pay a hundred (or hundreds of) dollars for a famous bandâ€™s show, but only some quarters for a local bandâ€™s?

The answer lies on a kinda addiction, a psychopathology indeed: people canâ€™t decide for themselves, they need someone to tell â€™em whichâ€™s right and whichâ€˜s wrong.

Without an authority telling what they must like, people get confused and lost.

So, back in 50â€™s, the Rockâ€™nâ€™Roll got exposed to the mainstream media, starting the first Rockâ€™s boom, that lasted until the end of the 70â€™s.

That gave a lesson to the music industry: they needed to classify, label, and fit into a box every future musical expression, in order to control it.

And it happened that way in 90â€™s: the second Rockâ€™s boom was industry driven. Only the songs that fit into the music industryâ€™s desirability could come to the mainstream light.

As well as the bands could be successful only under industryâ€™s terms, their songs was controlled too: even when a band had 2 or 3 hits got into the media, if the rest sounded unlike them, the band tended to be forgotten â€“ literally driven to oblivion. The music industry doesnâ€™t tolerate diversity.

So we grow up programmed to depend on the music industry to tell us what we must like or dislike.

That program tells us that famous band worths a hundred dollar ticket, but the local one â€“ as good and qualified as the first â€“ doesnâ€™t. We donâ€™t even question it.
